article.p: You've deployed BCHS. Your editor is open. Where do you begin?

section.p: Be familiar with CGI and FastCGI.
Install and use kcgi or fcgi from packages.

If you don't want to parse content by hand—and you really, really don't—let a library do it for you. (Want FastCGI? Think twice. CGI scripts run by slowcgi(8) already have their privileges dropped and file-system constrained. With FastCGI, you'll need to do it yourself.)
Get to know your security tools. OpenBSD has systrace(4). FreeBSD has capsicum(4).

Your application will be under assault every moment it's running. And it will have bugs: limit the damage caused by inevitable mistakes by constraining (sandboxing) the environment available to your application.
Statically scan your binary with LLVM (from packages).
This static analysis tool can help catch source-level bugs. An alternative compiler can also prevent you from relying too much on gcc(1)'s extensions, which reduces portability.
Run your application under valgrind (from packages) and make sure your malloc.conf(5) flags are unforgiving.
Memory errors are often the subtlest. Use these tools as much as possible to catch any unnoticed allocation issues.
Parsing data? Push your parsers into libraries and use AFL (from packages) to put them through inputs you haven't tested.
The thought that this input could never happen is your adversary's favourite. It will happen. Make sure any parsing sequences are being run through as many code-paths as possible with this tool.

article.p: Don't forget: BSD is a community of professionals. Go to conferences (EuroBSDCon, AsiaBSDCon, BSDCan, etc.). Subscribe to the mailing lists. Donate. And lastly but most important of all: use the man pages!
